segments.text: And I have the pleasure of being in Corpus Christi and chatting with Dick Connolly, the president of the association 1958 and 1959.
Now I'll stop and hope that the machine is working.
Mr. Connolly, as we begin,
Tell me, why did you go to A&M?
How did you happen to get to A&M in the first place?
Well, back in the days of the time I graduated from high school in 1931, there were tough times for most people, and my father had gone through two very serious business
failures.
One due to World War I in Athens, Georgia where I was born.
He was an automobile dealer.
When the war came along, he could no longer get cars and his business folded as a result.
He picked Palm Beach, Florida to go to get into the real estate business for seeking hopefully to
get a place where he could make a living for his four children and my mother Dixie.
There we lived for about four years during the Florida boom but again there were two Florida hurricanes came along and a boom burst in Venice and Wall Street and it was jumping out of windows and
his business there folded, so he picked Corpus Christi, Texas.
That's going a long way around to tell you how tough things were for us and many other people in those days, but he couldn't help me go to college.
So when I graduated, I was working as a
shipping autoclick for the Ranges Converse Company here in Corpus Christi, watching the boats go in and out of our harbor.

And I was fortunate enough to have a friend who I thought might know some of the Likes brothers, Ripley Steamship Company people, and she did, Mr. Roy, Ms. Roy Miller, who at that time was, I believe, the mayor of the city.
Anyway, he got me a job and I spent two years
nearly two years at sea as a deck boy and ordinary seaman, which was a great experience, but still didn't get me to make me enough money to go to college.
One day I was dating a very lovely girl named Bernice Wilder, the daughter of a state road contractor.
I came to pick her up late
one afternoon to take her to a picture show at a summer fair and was met by her father, Harry Wilder, at the door and said to come in and that Bernice would be down shortly.
So we went out on the porch, didn't have any air conditioning back in those days, and sat in the swing and we visited a bit and he said, Dick, why don't you go to college?
I said, well, Mr. Wilder, I haven't been able to afford to go to college.
I'd love to go to college.
He said, well, if you had a job at Texas A&M, say, for instance, could you go to college?
I said, Mr. Wilder, if I had a job, I could make it anywhere.
And he put his arm around my shoulder and took me to the bottom of the stairs of his home there and picked up the telephone and dialed some numbers and
Got Bob Ferguson, the governor at that time, on the line.
After swapping a few pleasances with her, he said, Miss Ferguson, I have a young friend that I'm very interested in.
I'd like to see him have the opportunity to go to college.
I wonder if you could get him a job at Texas A&M this coming fall.
They talked back and forth and he hung up, put his arm around me and he says, now, Nick, you've got a job at A&M.
You go up there.
And so on the strength of that, no letter, no any other thing, I hitchhiked for motor transportation mainly back in those days with my big suitcase.
I got into A&M about sundown, I remember, late one evening.
The first, as I walked in from the old train station there on the highway, heading toward Old Main, the first building on my left was Law Hall.
That's where the A Troop Cavalry was.
That was one of the best the good Lord was looking after me because I went in there and asked directions.
They said, well, come right on in here.
We got a bunk for you.
So I joined the A Troop Cavalry at that time.
Well, the second day after I registered,
My name was called over the loudspeaker at Savisa Hall, I believe it is, at West Hall, Cadet R.N.
Connolly, report to Secretary S.G. Bailey at the main administration building.

Well, I had to get directions where to go down there, and I, right after lunch, I walked down and walked into that beautiful new administration building, which, thank goodness, has recently been named the Jack Williamson Building.
I was amazed at his beauty, and I overcome with it, really, and I walked up those parallel stairs to Mr. Bailey's office.
I was rushing in by his secretary, and I looked at Mr. Bailey, and he looked at me, and he said, Son, are you Cadet R.N.
Connolly?
I said, Yes, sir, Mr. Bailey.
He said, well, son, you've got some powerful friends.
So through the goodness of a friend, Harry Wilder, and his friendship with Governor Mark Ferguson, I had a job from the day I entered A&M to the day I left.
It wasn't an easy job.
because I had to get up around 4.30 or 5 every morning and sweep.
My building was the old civil engineering building.
That was my responsibility.
I swept it from top to bottom, cleaned the waste paper baskets, and on Saturdays, cleaned the windows, trimmed the shrubs, cut the grass, if I remember, and cleaned the crappers.
Let's see, describe that trip from Corpus Christi to College Station, that first trip.
Did you go the whole way by train or hitchhike part of it?
Well, my father wanted, was so proud that I was going to A&M.
He had gone to the University of Georgia two years, but had left to go into business for himself.
But he had to go to Houston on business, so he took me as far as
Hempstead, I believe, or Hempstead, and let me out there and I hitchhiked with my big suitcase.
What did you have in that suitcase?
What did a freshman take to college in that era?
Back in those days, you know, not much different than it is today, I don't imagine, in that sense I had
Knowing that I was going to go, really wanted to go into the Corps, I researched that a little bit and the government was going to be furnishing me a uniform.
I had the best of whatever way I had.
I had a good suit in there and a lot of changes of shirt and underwear and whatever I felt like I needed but haven't been
a deck boy, an ordinary seaman on a ship, I learned to get around and get along with very little in a way of fancy clothes.
Please describe the campus when you arrived physically.
What buildings were there and where were they?
Where did people live?
Well, you know, back in those days, we had a relatively small student body.
It was probably around 6,000, maybe 6,500 if I'm not mistaken.
And we each had this, we were all military and we had a rather versatile military organization there with many different types of choices.
I picked the cavalry.

Because before you went up there, I had made up my mind that's where I wanted to go because I loved horses and to me it was the elite service, just like the Air Force later became the, you might say, the elite service.
But the law hall was right next to another hall.
I can't remember all those hall numbers, right close to the YMCA, which was a very important focal point on the campus in those days.

Down in the basement, Casey had his Sparks, and if I'm not mistaken, there was a barbershop down there, and they had their pharmacy where we could go down and get a milkshake every now and then, but mainly we made friends quickly with Sparks and Casey.
Casey particularly was a great individual, and I'll have to tell you a story about Casey later.
But to answer your story, a lot of the buildings that were there then have been torn down now.
Old Main was there.
Many of our classes were in Old Main.
And the headquarters for the university were down in the new administration building pretty well.
They didn't have a system back in those days, or any system building of course, but we did have a coliseum there for, we had our intramural athletics.
The intramural athletics formed a big part of taking the energy out of those students.
We didn't have any women around,
So we all took parts, and we got up early in the morning.
We went all day, and in the afternoon, we had a spare time.
We were out there playing intramural sports.
Describe what it was like to be a fish in that era.
How was a fish treated in his outfit?
Well, they were treated like fish.
In a sense, newcomers had to be trained.
I was never treated unkindly unless I voted on myself.
We had the military system that we had as far as
my A Troop Calvary was concerned and what I observed from others.
They picked good leaders who had good character and with good leadership roles.
I know my captain was, my freshman year there was Zeb Burke.
B-U-R-K?
B-U-R-K, yeah.
And I don't know what ever happened to Zeb, but I couldn't stay in touch with him.

His top kick was Ed Neal, who later moved to Beeville and was the extension director there, and a noted specialist in Hawaiian animal health and did a great job at that Beeville Experimental Station throughout his career, where he ended up and is now farming there now.
was a very kindly person who took an interest in all the freshmen and so did Frank Schleicher, the top kick to him.
And they all were gentlemen, they all treated you fairly.
But if you stepped out of line, you could get a whack on your butt.
And I did that occasionally.
I stepped out of line until I learned that that wasn't the thing to do.
I remember one Sunday morning,
I had presented up out late at night on one Saturday night.
I figured, well, no one's going to be around here Sunday.
They're all going to Austin.
I'm just going to lock this door and sleep in.
And nobody knows the difference.
Of course, I was supposed to be up even on Sunday morning and checking to see what the
and the top kicker and the others might need to help them shine their shoes and boots and so forth.
But so the next morning when I heard outside, I heard Zeb Berger say, oh, Ed Lee, Ed Neal, well, these freshmen, I need somebody to shine my boots.
Oh, I need someone to get me some coffee.
No answer from anywhere, no freshmen around.
Well, where's Dick Conley?
I thought he was going to be here this weekend.
No answer.
I heard all this behind a locked door.
I said, oh my gosh.
Anyway, Frank said, the top kick said, well, look, I've got a key to Conley's room.
I'll go in there and get his polishing kit.
And we'll see if we can clean our own boots.
So he opened the door and there I was in the sack.
Well, they gave me a lesson that I'll not remember, not forget.
And I never did anything like that again, but it was a good lesson.
Did you all do duck walks and other things like that?
Well, you know, they were very considerate of me because I was
working my way through school, and they knew it.
They knew I was a janitor, and I got up early every morning, 4.35 or 4, while they were still in the psych, and they respected that.
And because of that, I was never subject to any type of tomfoolery, you might say,
Some of the others didn't have to put up with all in the name of good training.
But I was getting that good training another way.
Describe a typical day of classes from the time you got up till the time you went to bed that night.
What happened when and for how long?
Well, when the bugle sounded, we were
put on our socks, jumped out of that bed and made it quickly in an army style and cleaned up.
And then we raced down to get in line, line up as we had three formations a day to go into the mess hall.
And where'd y'all line up?
We'd line up right in front on the street, right in front of Law Hall.
Okay.

We had our top kicks and we had our sergeants who were there to keep us in line and we took pride in our marching and always had as we went into the mess, oh, there's a piece of a roar of some song or something we were singing.
It was all a lot of camaraderie and

Those men who lined up with me were lifelong friends, like Omar Smith was a cavalryman, and Omar went on to have the tennis court named after him, and I can tell a different story about, well, later, about Omar that might not be a proper place for it here, but those friends were lifelong friends.
All right, you...
You got up, the Reveille was at what time?
Got up usually about 6 o'clock or 6.30.
I guess it was around 6.30 because we were lined up at 7 and the mess hall about 7.30 if I remember and maybe
Well, we were in full classes.
It was 8 o'clock every morning.
And we walked everywhere we went.
A few people had bicycles, but as you looked at the A&M campus, it was just students walking everywhere with hooks under their arms and a sling over their shoulder.
All right, then before lunch, did you fall in again?
We fell in again before lunch.
And the same here at night and in the evening.
Usually the evening performance was a little more special than the one at noon.
And sometimes at noon, we had formation three times a day.
All right, after supper, what was the typical routine on a weeknight?
Did you go back to your room?
Did you go play somewhere?
We had a little camaraderie usually over our meal in the evening, and usually we'd get out with a few of our buddies and walk around the lounge under the shade of a tree and bowl a little bit.
But we all had studies, and I had to get up early the next morning, so it was a routine for me to pretty well head back to my room and go to work.
All right.
Describe the routine in Sabisa Hall at mealtime for a freshman.
Where did you sit and what did you all do during the meal?
Well, the best I can remember
Of course, so many of us, they didn't shave my head.
My head was short, necessarily, anyway.
Very little shaving back in those days.
But we sat, it was, on the property, we sat extremely correct.
And we had, of course, certain rules we had to follow.
And the officers and
A couple of freshmen were fed, always served by the freshmen first.
And we got what was left, but it was always plenty.
And if we particularly
Fond of dessert, we would usually stick an extra piece of pie, a sweet roll or something under our shirt and carry it out frequently.
Did the food have nicknames in those days?
Oh, yes.
Please share some of those nicknames.
Well, dessert was kush always, and I recall meat was bull.
Bull neck?
Well, they had a nickname for practically every one of them, most of the vegetables.
And meat, bull neck, bull neck for meat.
Bread, ketchup, tea.
For everything they had some sort of nickname.
I don't remember all the details.

uh let's see uh was your freshman roommate did he become a special friend i had three roommates unfortunately unfortunately my first one was paul moore paul moore was a great young man from beeville taking veterinary science and paul moore
It was difficult for him to concentrate and he had trouble and he had to drop out at the end of his first semester.
But Paul went ahead and did graduate from a vet school and became the number two veterinarian at King Ranch.
He worked for Dr. Northrup and got some valuable training.
And just a wonderful man with a lot of personality, but he had one weakness, and that was barley corn.
And as so many people at the King Ranch did, he drank too much and it affected his life.
And the other one following him was Cliff Hardwick.
how do we get a gin people out of Sherman?
And he was a sort of a privileged young man because his father was a manufacturer and rather wealthy, I think, because he was one of the few that had money and had an automobile off campus.
But Cliff was a good friend, but we just didn't have the right chemistry.
and he went to room with someone else the following semester.
He was killed, incidentally, in one of the first horse cavalry episodes in the Philippines.
The machine gun was killed there early.
But Cliff was always a good friend.
And then I had...
Ralph McCambell, a rancher from Hebronville.
He was a sophomore while I was a junior.
Yeah, when I was a sophomore, he was a freshman, came as a freshman, but I wanted him because he was a Corpus Christi.
Your outfit was very special to you as you look back on it, your core outfit.
What made it special?
leadership and the friends that I made there and the camaraderie and the pride in their unit.
And a troop was always a special troop and a cavalry of the elite service as far as we were concerned.
And I think it's pretty well recognized at that time back in those days that the cavalry won.
Did you all have a nickname for the outfit?
No, it just stayed true.
How did you describe your dress when you went to class?
What did you wear to class?
Well, the government issued you your Army uniform, and that was part of being in the military and taking the military, and we wore a uniform religiously.
Please describe some of the pranks or the jokes or the good bull that you were aware of that occurred while you were a student.
Well, there again, I worked so hard, I say worked so hard, I had such a regimen that was so full
I was interested in acrobatics and had an opportunity through Penny to work with the tumbling team.
And then I was in the cavalry and very quickly got involved in polo and in monkey drill squad.
And that's something a lot of people never heard of.
But the monkey drill squad was an acrobatic and trick riding group.
And we had an old army sergeant
who was an artist at this type of thing, and he trained us.
Tell them about that.
I've not heard about the Monkey Drill Squad before.
Well, I've got some pictures of it, I'm sure to you.
We had a... With his help and Captain Robertson, we had two outstanding cavalry officers.
Major Ross Irvin and Captain Marcella Roberts.
And they were both unusually well qualified men with lots of interest and humor and made the cavalry work we did interesting.
And of course we did the hoodoos and we camped.
trained to shoot .50 caliber machine guns.
We fired pistol mounted and dismounted.
We were expert at sharpshooter and we were always into things that were active and fun.
Where did, where were the cavalry horses stabled?
They had a special stable area there like
West of the tracks?
Oh yes, west of the tracks, there was.

How many horses have... Well, I think there must have been 40, 50 horses, or better, maybe 60, 70, that we had of that group where the sergeant, I wish I could name his name, was bald-headed, red-faced, short, stout,

tough as a bull and he knew those horses and he picked the best ones for our monkey trail squad because we would ride them bareback with a surcingle and you'd stand on the horse and ride in a circle in a corral you might say and then we'd ride two abreast and three abreast and we'd build pyramids and then we would
through the use of the search angle, you'd vault from one side of the horse to the other as you galloped.
And you would learn to let the momentum of the horse as it swung forward to bring you back up in standing position.
And it had a lot of romance to it and a lot of fun.
Where did you all perform?
Well, we performed like the polo team, you know, at different times it was announced.
And mainly it was an activity that didn't get much publicity, but it was done because we all enjoyed it so much.
Kind of like an NMU sport, didn't get a whole lot of publicity.
How different was it in that time to be a sophomore in the Corps of Cadets than to be a freshman?
Describe being a sophomore for me.
Well, as a sophomore, I never was hazed myself, you know.
As I say, I paddled a few times pretty hard.
But if I did, I deserved it.
And I knew I deserved it.
And I knew whatever infraction I did, that I'd probably get a good filing from one of them.
But it was administered in a manly way and in a fair way.
And, you know, it was never an abusive thing.
And the sophomores, of course, we
We had these various different traditional things that they did.
But I didn't take part in most of them because of my work or the work that I had to do.
And they respected that.
Any of us that had jobs like I had in the janitor corps that was demanding and got you up real early, they made special dispensation for that.
An important question.
Please describe some of the important teachers and advisors that affected your life there.
Well, I was always tried to be
I was interested in my subjects and the toughest thing was my chemistry.
